NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR / Updated By Ken Dilanian and Courtney Kube NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR WASHINGTON — A senior congressional aide who has been briefed on the deaths of four U.S. servicemen in Niger says the ambush by militants stemmed in part from a "massive intelligence failure." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Pentagon has said that 40 to 50 militants ambushed a 12-man U.S. force in Niger on Oct. 4, killing four and wounding two. The U.S. patrol was seen as routine and had been carried out nearly 30 times in the six months before the attack, the Pentagon has reported. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he is not authorized to speak publicly, said the House and Senate armed services committees have questions about the scope of the U.S. mission in Niger, and whether the Pentagon is properly supporting the troops on the ground there. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There was no U.S. overhead surveillance of the mission, he said, and no American quick-reaction force available to rescue the troops if things went wrong. If it weren't for the arrival of French fighter jets, he said, things could have been much worse for the Americans. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Congress also has many unanswered questions about what happened, he said, including about the specifics of the mission that day and the accounts lawmakers have been given about the timeline of the attack and rescue. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The aide said questions are being asked about whether the U.S. soldiers were intentionally delayed in the village they were visiting. He said they began pursuing some men on motorcycles, who lured them into a complex ambush. The enemy force had "technical" vehicles — light, improvised military vehicles — and rocket-propelled grenades, the official said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR After the rescue when it became clear that one soldier was missing, "movements and actions to try and find him and bring him back were considered. They just were not postured properly [to get him]." The body of Sgt. La David Johnson was not recovered until nearly 48 hours after the Oct. 4 attack. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Pentagon spokesperson called the claim of an intelligence failure "speculation." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "An investigation is underway," said the spokesperson. "At the conclusion of the investigation, we will provide further details." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Thursday, Director of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Lt. Gen. Kenneth McKenzie said that "every tactical engagement doesn’t necessarily proceed from an intelligence failure. We'll look at it and we'll come to conclusions about how intelligence could have supported adequately or inadequately the engagement that occurred. But on a battlefield, the enemy gets a vote." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Sub-Saharan Africa is a very difficult place to operate," said Gen. McKenzie. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Friday afternoon, Defense Secretary James Mattis met with Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, to discuss the Niger raid. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier this week, McCain said the committee had not been provided with the information about the Niger mission that it "deserves." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said Congress will require more information from a Trump administration that is expanding counterterrorism operations across the globe. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Trump is loosening the rules of engagement when it comes to lethal action against terrorists, and expanding the counterterrorism fight to different parts of the world, including across Africa, Graham said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The war is morphing," he said. "You're going to see more actions in Africa, not less." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In that context, Graham said, "I will insist that Congress is informed more often and in more detail," about military operations. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He added, "As the war expands, as the military had more authority, Congress is going to require more information."
